items.text: An app that analyzes your text and not only gives practical answers based on word amount, rewriting and difficulty of writing text.

The app, called "FocusFlow," aims to combat information overload by curating and prioritizing content for users. It's designed for busy professionals, students, and anyone overwhelmed by the constant influx of information. FocusFlow works by using an AI algorithm that assesses user preferences and interaction patterns to select and organize relevant content—news articles, emails, social media updates, etc.—into manageable segments. Users can input specific interests, leading the app to highlight key information and summarize longer texts. Data generated includes user engagement metrics, content preferences, and feedback on the relevance of curated items. FocusFlow is useful because it saves users time and mental energy, allowing them to focus on what truly matters. Its innovative aspect lies in its adaptive learning feature, which continuously evolves by incorporating user feedback and external trends, ensuring that the content remains fresh and pertinent. This dynamic approach to information management can help reduce stress and enhance productivity.

A rating system for website and data reliability. The URL or file with data/the website is put into the app and assessed regarding how fitting it still is in the context of the current time, how good sources of data used are, if potential gaps in data/information are explainable and more. It would be especially useful to put information into a context and compare it to similar data/information to understand its validity. It could also filter out specific unreliable information and correct it. The system could run on AI or a wide database of comparable information or both.

My app would deal with fields of knowledge and evaluate your mental capacity. Just like with social media, it would ask you first for topics that you are not only interested in and occupied with. If it is something in your personal life including university and relationships or something that you would like to inquire into like politics or arts or maths - it is a life companion app and evaluates how much energy you have left to think and what is occupying your time/energy most and what is draining you. You would have to fill out a reflection after each day stating what you did and what you think about and what you would rather think about. So for example if I would like to engage in a political topic, AI wouldn't only evaluate my energy levels but also if there are necessary smaller steps to learn before diving into the deep end. Yallah

Asks for information input by user, what information does the app have to sort. Asks user to create priorities on what information is the most important. Structure the information based on the importance scale. Give user input on how to work with the given information. Question user on given topics, does he or she understand what the topics are about. What does he not understand? Create explanations and examples with the help of AI to support user with his or her information overload.

Information overload can be dealt with through multiple means, all of which the app should be capable of; 1. Organisation: The app should be able to aid organizing the information in order to effectively mitigate the stress of information overload. 2. Reduction: Information overload may be induced through an excess of unnecessary information, which the app should be able to help with by marking paragraphs with keywords or umbrella sentences. 3. Reintroduction: Information that was cut to reduce stress may be needed for the user. That is why the app should reintroduce the more detailed or complex information gradually, and in a manner that doesn't overstimulate the user.

A potential app idea could be to design an app that limits the user's time on social media to perhaps one or two hours a day, as well as force them to take small breaks in between. The app could possibly also manage the user's feed and filter out irrelevant information (information the user previously declared as uninteresting to them). The improvement of social media apps to limit fake news content or sensational "news" content could also improve the feeling of information overload a user experiences. The aforementioned app could be called MediaFilter.

App consists of different paragraphs and can process data and give feedback. AI is used for that task. All sorts of data can be uploaded in the app and then the app can collect this data and create things based on it. For example, Quizlets, questionnaires and other stuff like this. Also, all the data that is being uploaded in this app stays there till the user does not delete the app so one account can access all the information. Really useful for the tasks for universities or preparing invoices, because of AI which analyzes the data and can give what the user wants based on their prompt. For example, document "DataXlecture information" consists of notes from the lecture and after the analysis, AI "remembers" what is in it. So, when the user asks "give me a description of AI", they would receive an exact rule and not some random from the internet. As for invoices, a person can ask "how many hours Frau X worked in the company", and they would receive it. So this app is rather helpful with dealing with a lot of information. It can be used in other cases also, I just mentioned a couple of them so you will know examples for applications of this app.

I would make an app that filters news. I could break down complicated systems maybe in a short creative way so that more people interact with e.g. politics. I feel that most are not able to comprehend what is going on with the world because it is all mostly negative and just too much we see on the news/on social media. I think that most are also apprehensive to politics because it is all interconnected. I would also include some positive news because it often gets overlooked. Maybe you could also filter by ability to process information and obviously by region and time.

The app would filter news articles from selected newspapers and magazines (up to 10 different sources). It can be used by everyone who registered and activates an account. They select manually topics of interest beforehand (politics, humanities, television etc.) and get a listing of relevant articles regarding these topics every day. On top of that, 3 random other articles that might correlate to their interest are shown, to keep the variety broader. It’s useful because information and news in daily life tend to be quite overwhelming. With a filter and a lens, it might be easier to actively understand the topics on a deeper level.

I'd like to make an app that helps you with building decks and strategizing for the card game Magic: The Gathering. There are thousands of cards, and new innovative cards come out each year that possibly have amazing synergy with old cards that were before deemed useless/not that strong. The app will help you by recommending you certain cards for your deck after giving it basic information about what kind of deck you want to build. For that, of course, all cards must be scanned and put in a database, and an AI must be trained on game tactics. It will be useful to help new players navigate through the vast possibilities and make the game more beginner-friendly and fun in general.

It is going to be a program which controls the time spent on social media by the user. It will involve screen blocking in case the user goes over the limit which is set by the user. When trying to access the blocked app, the user receives the notification in a form of recommendation to spend the leisure time more appropriately, again based on the hobbies indicated by the user at the first launch of the program. On top of that, the program can include the optimized searching based on the keywords and the topics. For instance, one may search for the particular news about the keyword "NASA", while including or excluding certain websites or languages in the potential news source, etc. This provides the focused search according to the personalized criteria.

Make an app that helps people who lost their homes in a flood or are suffering due to a flood. The app allows you to register yourself and there will be other people who can register to give help. There would be different things you can contribute to someone; you see the name of the person and they have mentioned what help they need, like food, maybe a place to live or money, and you can directly give it to that person by contacting them there. Maybe there can be a middleman who can provide the need directly to the person.

My app will act as an information filter. It will allow users to enter some personal details/interests, based on which they will get relevant information around global politics. It will also always provide the option to expand on different relevant topics, to prevent unintentional filter bubbles. The app will also provide helpful tips on how to categorize information and help with symptoms of stress and burnout. It will offer (local) initiatives to support or join that can help with feelings of helplessness.
